titleStmt.title: Sheikh 'Nad Harran

monogr.title: A Digital Dictionary of Shawi Arabic

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the teiCorpusHeader prefix are pointers to any element in the SHAWI teiCorpus document.
Private URIs using the share prefix are pointers to audio file residing on the SHAWI network share.
Private URIs using the geo prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a place element in VICAV Geodata list.
Private URIs using the zotid prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a biblStruct element in the TEI export of the VICAV Zotero Group library.
Private URIs using the dict prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a entry in the SHAWI glossary.
Private URIs using the rend prefix are pointers to the xml:id attribute on a rendition element in VICAV rendition library.
Private URIs using the assets prefix are pointers to the location of the SHAWI media assets.

spanGrp.span: Once upon a time, master Stephan, there was big sheikh; he was a tribal chief, he had his men, his tents, sheep and camels. (One day) he, his name was Sheikh ʕNād, said to his slave;
ʕNād called his slave and said, “My slave, I want you to go to such and such a region, to such and such place. There is something there.”
He knew him; that one is a big sheikh and he has a daughter whose name is Sitte ʕAdle.

“You should go and ask for Sitte ʕAdle’s hand for me! You should ask for her hand so that her father gives her to me as a wife. If her father asks you about anything, deal with it according to your milk!”

I mean, he said to his slave, “Act according to your milk! Talk about me according to your milk! You know me well, I mean you are my slave. Talk according to your milk, I do not want anything else from you!”
He said, “Alright, my sheikh!” The slave went away and he had mounted warriors with him: They all went together and eventually arrived at the place of Sitte ʕAdle’s father.
“Welcome, welcome!” Her father welcomed them. He did not answer, but (the sheikh) kept saying, “Welcome!” He was welcoming the slave.
In former times, no one here used to give the slave any value; he was just a slave, a servant. But since he saw him (with the warriors), he thought that he would be a master of something.
“Welcome, my brother, come in please!” He hosted them. “Tell (us) why...” They were treating them well and generously for three days.

We Arabs, in former times, the sheikhs of the tribes, if someone would receive guests, they would not ask them for three days, “What is the purpose of your travel?” (lit. Why are you going, why are you coming?)
He would not say anything but only treat him well and generously. He would host him, feed him and give him to drink, but he would not ask him until the third day.
“O you guest of the merciful, my guest, what is the purpose of your travel?” He would say, “Well, o merciful host.” He means the owner of the tent.
“O merciful host, we have come (because) my sheik, Sheikh ʕNād, has sent... We were just passing by from here.” – He did not ask for her hand [I want to make it wrong].

“We passed by from here as guests. He told me that sheikh so-and-so is there, let’s say, Sheikh Ismāʕīl. Go to him and if you pass by from there, greet him from me!’ He will host you, he is a good man.”

He said to them, “Why are you travelling?” He said, “Well, we don’t want anything, we are neither going not coming. We do not want anything from you. We were just passing by and so we became your guests.”
He said, “Welcome, it was a pleasure for me (lit. on my head)!” He did not tell them. He did not ask for Sitt ʕAdle’s hand. He sent them (away) and they came back to Sheikh ʕNād.
“Well, the faces are not the faces (it was obvious from their faces that they did not anything); when he came back, the slave’s face looked bad.
He said, “My slave! What did you do?” He said, “Well, o Sheikh ʕNād, we went to Ismāʕīn, to Sheikh Ismāʕīn, the father of Sitte.
But they do not accept (you), neither he nor Sitte. They do not accept you, they do not want you.
He said (to us), ‘Who is this (guy)? Who is he then that he can ask for my daughter’s hand? How can I give him a woman? Who is he? What is this (guy)?’”
He was insulting him, he offended him, I mean he was really offending him.
Sheikh ʕNād said, “O my Lord!” He said, “I know that man, he should not insult me.

Isn’t there anything but good between me and him? Is there nothing but good between him and me? The good thing and the... real honesty, familiarity, sincere affection and good conversation. Tsk! O God!”
Sheikh ʕNād thought about it for one or two or three days, then he mounted his horse and he alone hit the road to Sheik Ismāʕīl.
When he reached them, they said, “Welcome! Welcome, Sheikh ʕNād! Welcome to the sheikh!”
Just when he got off the horse they had already put a rug, a carpet beneath him so his feet would not hit the ground.
“Welcome! Welcome Sheikh ʕNād!” And Sheikh Ismāʕīl had come out to meet him saying, “Well, o my brother!”
He stayed at his place and said, “Brother, recently my slave passed by from here, he came to you. Didn’t he come to you? Didn’t I send my slave to you?”

He said, “Yes, you sent him. We asked him, ‘Why are you travelling?’ But he did not say anything to us. He only said that he passed by from here and he said, ‘My sheikh told me, if you go there, be guests at sheikh Ismāʕīl’s.’ And so, we received him as a guest.”

He said, “Didn’t he want anything from you?” He said, “No!” “Didn’t he tell you anything?” He said “No!” He said, “Actually, my brother, I want your daughter Sitte ʕAdle. I want to ask for her hand for me as a wife. Would you give her (to me)?”

He said, “You have already got her!” (To his men he said,) “Get up and prepare her!” “She is ready, you have got her and I have given her to you.” He got up and prepared Sitte ʕAdle for him, then he placed Sitt ʕAdle behind him on the horse, and that one brought her home, to his tent.
When he brought her home, he called the slave and said, “Get up and let me see!” He called his slave and said, “My slave, come here!” – “Go ahead, my sheikh!”
He said, “Recently I sent you to Sheikh Ismāʕīl to ask Sitte ʕAdle’s hand for me. So why did you go? What did you say to him?”
He said, “Sheikh ʕNād, when you sent me to Sheikh Ismāʕīl you said to me, ‘I want to send you to ask for Sitte ʕAdle’s hand for me,’ and you said to me,
‘Act according to your milk!’ And, my dear sheikh, if you excuse me, my milk is impure (i.e. he is a bastard) and you cannot ask me for the good thing.
You said to me, ‘Act according to your milk, but my milk is impure. My milk is not so pure that I can go and ask for you according to my milk.”
(The sheikh) did not show any reaction but said, “Since your milk is impure…” He said, “Brother, give him, give him..
help him, bring him a sword and he lopped off his head saying, “If your milk is impure, what are you doing at my place?” He lopped off his head and the matter was over. Enjoy it!
